payload.htmlContent:
**WP6. Developing a theoretical AI-Powered Energy Management Model** WP6 will demonstrate how IA can improve the smart grid stability and efficiency. - Implementing machine learning techniques (Markov models, neural networks) to optimize grid efficiency. - Creating predictive models for demand forecasting, outage prevention, and real-time grid monitoring. Deliverable: Technical report, academic manuscript.

Generated by Cirdi on Thursday, July 10, 2025

To address WP6, which focuses on developing a theoretical AI-Powered Energy Management Model, several relevant points from the provided context can be integrated:

  1. Implementation of Machine Learning Techniques:

    • The context mentions the development of models for simulation and control of micro-grids, which includes the deployment of monitoring tools and the collection of measurement data [1a], [1b]. This aligns with the goal of implementing machine learning techniques such as Markov models and neural networks to optimize grid efficiency.
    • The development of identification methods to correct and increase the quantitative capacity of prediction models [1a], [1b] supports the use of advanced machine learning techniques for grid optimization.

  2. Creating Predictive Models:

    • The context discusses the development of predictive models for simulation and control of micro-grids, including the use of weather and occupant behavior forecasts to develop anticipative and real-time control algorithms [1c]. This directly supports the creation of predictive models for demand forecasting, outage prevention, and real-time grid monitoring.
    • The development of models and optimization strategies for optimal anticipative and reactive management of micro-grids [1a], [1b] further supports the goal of creating predictive models for grid management.

  3. Deliverables:

    • The context mentions the development of technical reports and academic manuscripts as part of the research projects [1a], [1b], [1c]. This aligns with the deliverables specified for WP6.

In summary, the context provides strong support for the implementation of machine learning techniques and the creation of predictive models for smart grid management. The deliverables of technical reports and academic manuscripts are also well-aligned with the proposed activities.

Pour en savoir plus:
1a, 1b, 1c

Clean Energy and Sustainable Development lab activity report, 2014-09-31 to 2015-12-31

Minh Ha-Duong, Hoang Anh Tran (2016)
